title: 111_s2781
content:
Rosa's Law, also known as the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, amends various sections to replace "mental retardation" with "intellectual disabilities" in education laws. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 are amended to replace "mild mental retardation" with "mild intellectual disabilities" and "mental retardation" with "intellectual disability" in various sections. This aligns with Rosa's Law, which aims to update education laws regarding individuals with disabilities. The Health Research and Health Services Amendments of 1976 and the Public Health Service Act are amended to replace "mental retardation" with "intellectual disabilities" in various sections. The Health Research and Health Services Amendments of 1976 and the Public Health Service Act are amended to replace "mental retardation" with "intellectual disabilities" in various sections, focusing on research, prevention, and treatment of intellectual disabilities. (g) Health Professions Education Partnerships Act of 1998.--Section 419(b)(1) of the Health Professions Education Partnerships Act of 1998 is amended to replace "mental retardation" with "intellectual disabilities".
(h) Public Law 110-154.--Section 1(a)(2)(B) of Public Law 110-154 is amended to replace "mental retardation" with "intellectual disabilities".
(i) National Sickle Cell Anemia, Cooley's Anemia, Tay-Sachs, and Genetic Diseases Act.--Section 402 of the National Sickle Cell Anemia, Cooley's Anemia, Tay-Sachs, and Genetic Diseases Act is amended to replace "leading to mental retardation" with "leading to intellectual disabilities". SEC. 3. REGULATIONS. Regulations issued to carry out the provisions amended by this section will reflect the changes from "mental retardation" to "intellectual disabilities" in references and definitions. SEC. 3. REGULATIONS. Regulations amended by this Act will replace references to "mental retardation" with "intellectual disabilities" and clarify that individuals with intellectual disabilities were formerly referred to as individuals who are mentally retarded. This Act replaces the term "mental retardation" with "intellectual disability" and "individuals with intellectual disabilities" for "individuals who are mentally retarded". It does not intend to change coverage, eligibility, rights, responsibilities, or definitions in the law. States are not compelled to change their terminology.
